The phrase in Hebrew: טוֹב וָרָע / tov V'ra, translatable as good and evil, 
may be an example of the type of figure of speech known as merism. This 
literary device pairs opposite terms together, in order to create a general 
meaning; so that the phrase "good and evil" would simply imply 
"everything". It is equivalent to the Egyptian expression evil-good which 
is indeed normally employed to mean "everything". In Greek literature, the 
concept is also used by Telemachus, "I know all things, the good and the 
evil" (Od.20:309-10).[2] However, given the context of disobedience to God, 
other interpretations of the implications of this phrase also demand 
consideration.
